repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Third Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The rating for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was unlikely, the institutional development impact was
            modest, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was unsatisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that the Bank was aware that the new
            Government's electoral platform was often at odds with
            the reform agenda supported by Structural Adjustment Credit
            (SAC3). So, the Bank was faced with the choice of pursuing
            an adjustment operation, providing some budget support and
            continuing to engage in order to limit the reform reversals,
            or to disengage. It chose the former. It was the right
            decision because more serious policy reversals almost
            certainly would have occurred in the absence of SAC3. Tariff
            re-balancing, though partially undermined, probably would
            likely have been much delayed or not have taken place at
            all. A hospital restructuring plan for the further
            elimination of excess capacity in Chisinau Municipality
            Hospital and Republican Hospitals might never have been
            developed and the case against Union Fenosa might have
            actually led to cancellation of the privatization contract.
            Granting extensions can be costly to subsequent operations
            if it sets a precedent for noncompliance. In the case of
            Moldova, there was a mixture of delays and last minute
            scrambling to implement. In the end, the Government came up
            short in its implementation of second tranche conditions and
            adherence to the LDP.

repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Third Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Structural Adjustment Credit
            Project for Moldova provides budgetary support to help the
            Government consolidate economic stabilization, bolster
            foreign reserves, and service external debt. The program
            focuses on structural reform in key areas--agriculture,
            energy, reducing barriers to new enterprise formation, and
            telecommunications and winery privatization. At the same
            time, the program engenders improvements in the public
            sector to help ensure that the benefits of the structural
            reforms are broadly received. This Credit supports reforms
            within two broad agendas to help ensure sustained growth in
            Moldiva over the medium term: 1) reforms to reduce poverty
            through improving monitoring and evaluation of poverty
            reduction measures, improvement of the education system and
            the efficiency of health care delivery, and strengthening
            social protection; and 2) reforms to improve the business
            environment through implementation of hard budget
            constraints and improvement of fiduciary management,
            maintaining liberal market policies in the agriculture
            sector and further development of land and credit markets,
            securing the financial viability of the power sector by
            completing change of ownership/management control of the
            power companies and assuring the independence of the energy
            regulator, reducing administrative barriers to business
            entry and exit, reforming the institutional framework and
            procedures governing privatization, and liberalization of
            the telecom and winery sectors.
